HNSW represents a hierarchical extension of NSW, incorporating the principles of the probabilistic skip list. It features a minimal graph at the top layer, while the subsequent layers progressively increase in complexity.

- HNSW enhances retrieval speed and accuracy, especially in high-dimensional data tasks, by quickly locating the most similar document vectors in a vector database.

- Improving memory-efficiency practices to ensure seamless operation, even when working with large-scale datasets.
- Tuning hyperparameters, such as the exploration factor (ef), to optimize performance and resource usage.
- The creators of HNSW found that the best performance is achieved when we minimize the overlap of shared nrighbors across layers. But i don't know why. From my perspective, in the sorted linked list, the data have binary tree can have to find the solution in O(log(n)).

Oh, I see! When the dataset is divided into fewer chunks per layer—such as two chunks in the case of a binary tree—this effectively minimizes the overlap of shared neighbors across layers. In such structures, only k nodes tend to overlap (typically three in a binary tree: the start, the end, and the middle point).

notableObservations: The idea of using a probabilistic skip list in HNSW is inspired by the concept of chunking and the continuous search for the most optimal chunk.

Navigable small world models are defined as any network with poli or logarithmic complexity using greedy routing. The efficiency of greedy routing breaks down for larger networks (1-10K+ vertices) when a graph is not navigable.
For compact and navigable models, initiating the search from high-degree vertices—known as the zoom-in-first approach—has been shown to enhance performance on low-dimensional data.
Although HNSW offers high speed and accuracy, it remains suboptimal in terms of memory efficiency.
The best performance is achieved when we minimize the overlap of shared nrighbors across layers.
unexpectedInsights: The multi-layer search algorithm in the probabilistic skip list becomes inefficient for dense databases, where there are fewer layers but a larger number of nodes.
